title: 109_hr424
content: The Energy Efficiency Investment Act of 2005, also known as the "Energy Efficiency Investment Act," introduces a credit for energy-efficient property in residences and businesses under section 30B of the Internal Revenue Code of 1986. The Energy Efficiency Investment Act of 2005 offers a tax credit for qualified energy property, including energy-efficient building components and heating/cooling equipment that are Energy Star qualified. The credit is equal to 25 percent of the amount paid or incurred by the taxpayer for such property placed in service during the taxable year. The tax credit for qualified energy property under the Energy Efficiency Investment Act of 2005 applies to property that is the taxpayer's principal residence, has its original use with the taxpayer, and has a useful life of at least 5 years. Definitions for building envelope component, principal residence, and Energy Star qualified property are provided. The Energy Star program, managed by the EPA and DOE, sets guidelines and performance levels for residences based on climate region. The tax credit for qualified energy property has limitations based on the amount of tax liability. The tax credit for qualified energy property has limitations based on tax liability. Excess credit can be carried over to the next taxable year. Special rules apply to tenant-stockholders in cooperative housing corporations. The tax credit for qualified energy property allows individuals to claim their share of expenditures incurred for such property. This includes condominium owners who are part of a condominium management association. The credit is allocated appropriately to each individual. For tax purposes, a condominium management association is defined as an organization that meets specific requirements for a residential condominium project. Expenditures for labor related to qualified energy property are also included in the tax credit. If less than 80% of the property is used for nonbusiness purposes, only that portion of the expenditure is eligible for the credit. For nonbusiness purposes, only the portion of the expenditure properly allocable to use for nonbusiness purposes is eligible for the credit. If a credit is allowed for an expenditure on qualified energy property, the basis of the property is reduced by the amount of the credit. This applies to qualified energy property placed in service after December 31, 2004. The text introduces a new paragraph related to the allowance of a credit for a residence or property under section 30B, with a clerical amendment to the table of sections. The amendments made by this section apply to taxable years ending after December 31, 2004 for energy efficient property in residences and businesses.
